Blurb
Overview
Skill/Other Attribute 1:
"​
​Problem solving skills
"
How this is developed:
"problem solving case study workshops"

Skill/Other Attribute 2:
"​
Organisational skills
"
How this is developed:
"Self directed learning"
Educational Aims
This module aims to: ​

Develop  students knowledge of the immune system and its role in protection against disease;

Develop in students an appreciation of the importance of different immune mechanisms in different circumstances, and how these can be evaded;

Enable students to evaluate and appreciate the consequences of immune system dysfunctions in disease.​
Marketing Module Synopsis
The module will develop knowledge and understanding of the immune system, the molecules, cells and tissues that are involved in its function, its role in combating infection and how its dysfunction can contribute to disease.

Lectures will be supplemented with on-line resources. Problem solving workshops dedicated to case studies will be held to help students prepare for the assessments. Students will be given guided reading, and formative and summative assessment exercises held during the course will enable students to monitor and evaluate their progress and to prepare for the final assessment.

The module will be assessed by two assessments.
Outline Syllabus
Innate vs Adaptive Immunity;

Cells and Organs of the Immune System;

Innate Immunity;

Epithelial Surfaces and Complement;

Cellular Response and Inflammation;

Adaptive Immunity;

Lymphoid Development and Lympoid Tissue;

Immunoglobulin Structure and Function;

Generation of Antibody Diversity;

Humoral Immunity;

T-cell Development and Selection, TH1, TH2, TH17;

T-cell Mediated Immunity;

The Cellular Basis of Immunological Memory;

Immune Cell Signalling;

Cytokines;

MHC Structure and Diversity;

Antigen Presentation via the MHC I and II Pathways;

Mucosal Immunity;

Immunity to Bacteria and Bacterial Evasion Strategies;

Immunity to Viruses and Viral Evasion Strategies;

Immunity to Parasites and Parasite Evasion Strategies;

Failures of Host Defense Mechanisms - including clinical scenario case studies;

Allergy and Allergic Disease;

Autoimmunity and Transplantation;

Manipulating the Immune Response.                                                       
Teaching and Learning Methods
Learning and teaching will be delivered using a hybrid model with a combination of synchronous and asynchronous teaching methods.

Learning and teaching in this module are designed and delivered by research-active scientists to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research and best evidence (‘Research-connected teaching’, Liverpool Curriculum Framework).

Delivery methods may include PBL, flipped classrooms, polling, and discussions based on pre-lecture reading or recordings etc. These engage and challenge students in an active learning process, and coupled with independent learning, will build self-confidence (Liverpool Curriculum Framework.

Lecture and tutorial content, reading lists, and discussion between students and staff give the students an opportunity to experience and understand cultures other than their own. The formation of this inclusive approach fosters the values of respect and equality amongst the students and improves their global perspective (Global citizenship and Inclusivity, Liverpool Curriculum Framework).

Teaching Method 1 – e-Lecture (asynchronous and synchronous). Description: These sessions will comprise of pre-recorded lectures or live video lectures.
Teaching Method 2 – Online tutorials and problem-solving workshops (synchronous). Description: These will be sessions designed for discussion and consolidation of knowledge acquired in lectures as well as supporting related skills sessions. These tutorials/workshops will take place using an online platform. Attendance will be recorded.

“Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.”
Assessment Strategy
The assessments reflect real-life and career-based scenarios (Authentic assessment hallmark of the Liverpool Curriculum Framework). Students write two essays.

Specifically, these assessments enhance digital fluency in our students, a skill highly sought after by graduate employers. Additionally, we are creating confident graduates who will excel in their field. These authentic assessments are research-connected and the skills for completion are taught through active learning

Assessment 1 consists of a piece of written work submitted online (1000 words). The exact dates of which may vary slightly from year to year as they need to fit into the School Assessment Timetable, which may slightly change from year to year. Students are informed of the specific dates in week 1 of teaching, and they're available in the module handbook.

Assessment 2 will consist of a synoptic piece of written work of 1500 words. Students undertake workshops/interactive sessions which allow for discussion around immunological testing and diseases that enhance higher order thinking skills.
Assessment marks are aggregated to produce the final module mark.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

How this is developed:
"Self directed learning"
Educational Aims
This module aims to: ​

Develop  students knowledge of the immune system and its role in protection against disease;

Develop in students an appreciation of the importance of different immune mechanisms in different circumstances, and how these can be evaded;

Enable students to evaluate and appreciate the consequences of immune system dysfunctions in disease.​
Marketing Module Synopsis
The module will develop knowledge and understanding of the immune system, the molecules, cells and tissues that are involved in its function, its role in combating infection and how its dysfunction can contribute to disease.

Lectures will be supplemented with on-line resources. Problem solving workshops dedicated to case studies will be held to help students prepare for the assessments. Students will be given guided reading, and formative and summative assessment exercises held during the course will enable students to monitor and evaluate their progress and to prepare for the final assessment.

The module will be assessed by two assessments.
Outline Syllabus
Innate vs Adaptive Immunity;

Cells and Organs of the Immune System;

Innate Immunity;

Epithelial Surfaces and Complement;

Cellular Response and Inflammation;

Adaptive Immunity;

Lymphoid Development and Lympoid Tissue;

Immunoglobulin Structure and Function;

Generation of Antibody Diversity;

Humoral Immunity;

T-cell Development and Selection, TH1, TH2, TH17;

T-cell Mediated Immunity;

The Cellular Basis of Immunological Memory;

Immune Cell Signalling;

Cytokines;

MHC Structure and Diversity;

Antigen Presentation via the MHC I and II Pathways;

Mucosal Immunity;

Immunity to Bacteria and Bacterial Evasion Strategies;

Immunity to Viruses and Viral Evasion Strategies;

Immunity to Parasites and Parasite Evasion Strategies;

Failures of Host Defense Mechanisms - including clinical scenario case studies;

Allergy and Allergic Disease;

Autoimmunity and Transplantation;

Manipulating the Immune Response.                                                       
Teaching and Learning Methods
Learning and teaching will be delivered using a hybrid model with a combination of synchronous and asynchronous teaching methods.

Learning and teaching in this module are designed and delivered by research-active scientists to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research and best evidence (‘Research-connected teaching’, Liverpool Curriculum Framework).

Delivery methods may include PBL, flipped classrooms, polling, and discussions based on pre-lecture reading or recordings etc. These engage and challenge students in an active learning process, and coupled with independent learning, will build self-confidence (Liverpool Curriculum Framework.

Lecture and tutorial content, reading lists, and discussion between students and staff give the students an opportunity to experience and understand cultures other than their own. The formation of this inclusive approach fosters the values of respect and equality amongst the students and improves their global perspective (Global citizenship and Inclusivity, Liverpool Curriculum Framework).

Teaching Method 1 – e-Lecture (asynchronous and synchronous). Description: These sessions will comprise of pre-recorded lectures or live video lectures.
Teaching Method 2 – Online tutorials and problem-solving workshops (synchronous). Description: These will be sessions designed for discussion and consolidation of knowledge acquired in lectures as well as supporting related skills sessions. These tutorials/workshops will take place using an online platform. Attendance will be recorded.

“Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.”
Assessment Strategy
The assessments reflect real-life and career-based scenarios (Authentic assessment hallmark of the Liverpool Curriculum Framework). Students write two essays.

Specifically, these assessments enhance digital fluency in our students, a skill highly sought after by graduate employers. Additionally, we are creating confident graduates who will excel in their field. These authentic assessments are research-connected and the skills for completion are taught through active learning

Assessment 1 consists of a piece of written work submitted online (1000 words). The exact dates of which may vary slightly from year to year as they need to fit into the School Assessment Timetable, which may slightly change from year to year. Students are informed of the specific dates in week 1 of teaching, and they're available in the module handbook.

Assessment 2 will consist of a synoptic piece of written work of 1500 words. Students undertake workshops/interactive sessions which allow for discussion around immunological testing and diseases that enhance higher order thinking skills.
Assessment marks are aggregated to produce the final module mark.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

Learning Outcomes
 ReferenceOutcome

 LO2 ​Assess the contribution of innate and adaptive immune mechanisms to host defences
 LO3 Assess the mechanisms that permit recognition of an infinitely diverse microflora
 LO4 Discuss the impact of malfunction of immune processes on human health, and explain the bases of autoimmunity and allergy together with the mechanisms by which these can be minimised
 LO5 ​ ​Discuss how dysfunction of immune system constituents can cause disease
